title: 108_hr1106
content:
The "Fremont-Madison Conveyance Act" defines terms like "District" and "Secretary" and involves the conveyance of facilities. The Secretary of the Interior is required to convey water distribution and drainage system components to the Fremont-Madison Irrigation District in Idaho. If the conveyance is not completed by a certain date, a report must be submitted to Congress explaining the delay. The Secretary will require the District to pay administrative costs for the conveyance and related activities. Additionally, the District must pay the net present value of remaining obligations or $280,000 to the United States. Amounts received will go into the Reclamation Fund. SEC. 5. TETON EXCHANGE WELLS.

In conveying the Teton Exchange Wells, the Secretary shall transfer Idaho Department of Water Resources permit number 22-7022 and all equipment related to the wells. The water service contract between the Secretary and the District is extended until all conditions in this Act are met.

SEC. 6. ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW

Before the conveyance, the Secretary will conduct all necessary environmental reviews as outlined in the Memorandum of Agreement referenced in section 3(a).

SEC. 7. LIABILITY. SEC. 7. LIABILITY.

Effective upon conveyance, the United States will not be liable for damages arising from the conveyed facilities, except for negligence prior to the conveyance date. This does not increase liability beyond what is currently provided in title 28, United States Code. SEC. 8. The acreage eligible for water supply from the Minidoka Project and Teton Basin Projects in the District is increased to include lands annexed before the enactment of this Act. This increase does not affect existing water storage contracts or State water law. SEC. 9. DROUGHT MANAGEMENT PLANNING. Within 60 days of enactment, the Secretary will collaborate with stakeholders in the Henry's Fork watershed to start a drought management planning process for all water uses. Within 18 months, a final drought management plan will be submitted to Congress. SEC. 10. EFFECT. This section clarifies that the Act does not affect the rights of any person or the water rights of the Shoshone-Bannock Tribes. Conveyances under the Act will not impact any existing contracts or state laws related to water use.
